description.summary: Mountain god or deity in Shinto tradition. Appears in various forms depending on region, protects mountains and forests, transforms seasonally into Ta-no-kami (rice field god). Active worship continues at Shinto shrines.
description.full: Yama-no-kami, the mountain god or deity, is a significant kami (deity/spirit) in Japanese Shinto tradition and folklore. Unlike yokai, Yama-no-kami is a deity commanding reverence and respect, with active worship continuing at Shinto shrines throughout Japan. The kami's appearance varies significantly by region—depicted as an old woman in some areas, a beautiful woman in others, and even as a male deity in certain regions. One of the most distinctive aspects of Yama-no-kami is the seasonal transformation: in winter, the deity presides over mountains and forests, but in spring descends to the rice paddies and becomes Ta-no-kami (rice field god), returning to the mountains in autumn. This dual nature reflects the agricultural cycle and the deep connection between mountains and rice cultivation in Japanese culture. Yama-no-kami protects mountains, forests, and those who respectfully enter them—particularly hunters, woodcutters, and mountain travelers. Strict taboos surround interaction with the deity: cutting certain sacred trees, hunting on specific days, and disrespectful behavior can incur severe consequences including misfortune, accidents, or death. Hunters traditionally leave offerings before entering mountains and observe seasonal restrictions. The relationship with tengu (mountain spirits) varies by region, with some traditions viewing tengu as messengers or servants of Yama-no-kami. As a living religious tradition rather than folklore, Yama-no-kami worship reflects the ongoing Shinto reverence for nature spirits and the sacred character of mountains in Japanese spirituality.

physical.morphology: Deity without fixed physical form. Appearance varies by region and context. Capable of shapeshifting and seasonal transformation.

abilities.description: Guards mountains, forests, and wilderness areas
Becomes Ta-no-kami (rice field god) in spring, returns to mountains in autumn
Bestows fortune on respectful visitors, misfortune on disrespectful ones
Influence over mountain weather, wildlife, forest growth

patterns: Requires respect and offerings from visitors

range.description: Throughout Japan in Shinto tradition. Mountain shrines and sacred sites across the country. Regional variations in appearance and specific practices.

peak_activity_periods.description: Active worship continues at Shinto shrines

origins.cultural_roots: Ancient Shinto nature worship. Mountains are sacred in Japanese spirituality. Agricultural connection reflects rice cultivation importance.
origins.folklore_connections: Distinct from yokai folklore—Yama-no-kami is worshipped deity, not folklore creature. Represents living religious tradition.

timeline.significance: Mountain deity worship established in early Japanese religion
Seasonal transformation belief develops with rice agriculture
Active shrines and religious practices throughout Japan

history.modern_era: Yama-no-kami worship continues at Shinto shrines throughout Japan. Mountain festivals, seasonal ceremonies, and traditional practices remain active in rural and mountain communities.

stories: Hunters receiving blessings for proper respect
Misfortune befalling those who violate taboos
Seasonal transformation between mountain and field
folklore.beliefs: Mountains are sacred. Proper respect must be shown to mountain deity. Seasonal cycle connects mountains to agriculture. Nature deities deserve reverence.

indigenous.significance: Living religious tradition of Shinto faith. Represents sacred nature of mountains in Japanese spirituality. Not folklore but active worship.
indigenous.sensitivity_note: Yama-no-kami is part of LIVING SHINTO RELIGIOUS TRADITION. This is not folklore or mythology but actual religious belief and practice. Approach with full religious respect.
indigenous.respect_guidelines: Recognize as active religious tradition, not folklore curiosity. Show respect for Shinto beliefs and practices. Do not appropriate or trivialize religious traditions. Consult with Shinto authorities for sacred site visits.
